appearances.title: The Briefing with Jen Psaki: Weekend : MSNOW : January 12, 2026 1:00am-2:00am PST
appearances.snippet: when we were asking for the the national guard, the republican, mitch mcconnell was right. there wasn't even a profanity to say, send them right away, again and again and again. and the president wouldn't do it. and yet, when it was time to have the president answer for his actions, mitch mcconnell folded and just went down a different path. but again, we don't agonize. we organize for making the future better. i wear the future on my sleeve or under my sleeve. i have a faith, hope and love. and i say, if you believe in love and the goodness of the american people, that gives people hope. so rather than just focusing on him, which he does this in order to get attention, we want to show that the american people are good people and that our will honor the vision of our founders who respect the courage of our men and women in uniform. and we will be faithful to the aspirations of our children, and we will not let his lies take us away from that. >> no, and we want to keep working to preserve the memory of what happened that day. i wanted to play part of jack smith's testimony.

appearances.title: Washington Journal Mary Clare Jalonick : CSPAN : January 6, 2026 5:26pm-5:51pm EST
appearances.snippet: she and mitch mcconnell did approve the national guard after the riots started. i think the only way to make clear exactly what happened is to ask the people who were there themselves and do that reporting and get those facts out there. host: five years since the event, in your mind, have all the questions been answered? are there still questions in your mind? guest: absolutely. i think we know the set of facts that happen, but i think we are still processing it in a lot of ways, maybe the significance of it. there's certainly different people who have different perspectives on that, but there is not a lot of debate of the fact of what happened, the people broke into the building and temporarily stop the certification of aydin's victory, and then the violence that happened, that is something that was, to me, important to make clear, how violent the day was. i think some people try to downplay that violence, but it was a violent day. while i think we know that set of facts of what happened, i think we are still processing it and reckoning with it in a lot of ways.

appearances.snippet: mitch mcconnell, lindsey graham, the list goes on and on.e republican, they're done with them. but now power, they just crave that, that that desire to have donald trump's support because it seems like as americans, we had the opportunity to reject that in november. and we didn't we had an opportunity to get all these institutions, the failed institutions, failure to convict them in the senate, failure for the courts to hold him accountable. we had the opportunities, but the american people had the ultimate say so. and we didn't live up to what i thought that we were capable of as americans. so it's always important for us to continue to talk about this, especially why there's so much whitewashing going on. i said in my testimony when i testified before congress, how can we move on from january 6th without correcting what happened? and there has been no accountability yet. and the the little bit that we did have you saw with the president pardoned them, a criminal pardoning criminals. >> i will just note before we go that the two of you are

appearances.snippet: crit simple of my good friend -- a criticism of my good friend, john thune, or my good friend mitch mcconnell or my good friend chuck schumer. they're just following the rules. i'd change them. but we need to do another reconciliation bill to fix the welfare system and stop the stealing, stop the stealing. and we can do it with all republican votes. so please, senator thune -- pretty please, as i've said before -- i'm shameless; i'll beg; i'll get down on my knees. john, please bring another reconciliation bill. we can do so much, but we can start with fixing welfare fraud. please, john -- please let us do the bill. i don't want to end on a negative note. i might have hurt my back going down, mr. president. i don't want to end on that note. i love this country. i'm -- i just think america is the greatest country in all of human history. i do. and the whole world knows it. everybody knows it that comes here. when's the last time you heard somebody trying to sneak into china? no, they want to come to america. and i believe as much as i'm standing here that the future of this country can be bett
